title: Random Walks: Reflection Principle
contentHtml: The reflection principle is a fundamental concept in random walks.

theorem.statement: \[P(x_n = i | x_{n-1} = j) = \begin{cases} P(x_1 = i | x_0 = j), & n > 1 \\ \frac{1}{2}, & n = 1 \end{cases}\]
theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the probability of reaching a given point is equal to the probability of reflecting back from that point.

intuition: The reflection principle states that the probability of moving forward or backward in a random walk is equal, given the current position. This has important implications for understanding the behavior of random walks.
